Vol 4: Intention, Sincerity, and Truthfulness
The second truthfulness (Sidq) is in intention (Niyyah) and will (Iradah), and this returns to sincerity (Ikhlas), which is that there should be no motive in movements and stillness except Allah the Exalted. If it is mixed with a taint of the desires of the Soul (Nafs), the truthfulness of intention is invalidated, and its possessor may be called a liar, as we have narrated in the virtue of sincerity (Ikhlas) from the Hadith of the Three when the scholar is asked: 'What did you do with what you knew?' He said: 'I did such and such.' Allah the Exalted said: 'You have lied, rather you intended that it be said: So-and-so is a scholar.' The Hadith of the Three when the scholar was asked: 'What did you do with what you knew?' The Hadith has preceded, for He did not call him a liar and did not say to him: 'You did not act,' but He called him a liar in his will (Iradah) and intention (Niyyah). And some have said: 'Truthfulness (Sidq) is the soundness of monotheism (Tawhid) in purpose (Qasd).' Likewise, the saying of Allah the Exalted: 'And Allah bears witness that the hypocrites are liars.' And they said: 'Indeed, you are the Messenger of Allah.' And this is truthfulness, but their lying is not from the aspect of tongue utterance, but from the aspect of the heart's conscience (Damir Al-Qalb). And the calling liar pertains to the report, and this saying includes reporting by circumstantial evidence (Qarinah Al-Hal), since its possessor shows from himself that he believes what he says, so he lied in his indication by circumstantial evidence (Qarinah Al-Hal) to what is in his heart, for he lied in that and did not lie in what he utters. Thus, one of the meanings of truthfulness (Sidq) returns to the purity of intention (Niyyah), which is sincerity (Ikhlas), so every truthful one must be sincere (Mukhlis).
